This week, they sort of rolled out new version of privacy settings that are supposed to make it even easier for you to go on and fix and match your own level of privacy to what Facebook has for you.

VANESSA ROMO: But I'm just so - I'm so skeptical because we've heard apologies in the past. And we've heard these, you know, proclamations of, you know, mea culpa from Zuckerberg. And he promises that things will get better for users, and they won't be abused or sold.

SAM SANDERS: Yeah.

VANESSA ROMO: And yet, you know, here we are again, right? So is this actually real?

ALINA SELYUKH: There's this fundamental idea that's ingrained in the business model of Facebook and Google which is different from most other companies, even the largest ones like Apple or Microsoft, which is that they make most of their money by selling our data. So this kind of philosophical question gets tossed around a lot. There's been a lot of think pieces about this, which is who is the customer of Facebook?

SAM SANDERS: The advertisers are the customers. And the...

ALINA SELYUKH: We are...

SAM SANDERS: We're the product.

ALINA SELYUKH: ...The product.

SAM SANDERS: This time feels different, though, because I feel like there are people in Congress talking about doing something, right? Like, last week, a senator from Massachusetts, Democrat Ed Markey - he talked about, like, a privacy Bill of Rights.

(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)

ED MARKEY: That would guarantee that every American know when information is being gathered about them, know when that information is being reused for purposes other than which the consumer wanted it to be used. And third, and most importantly, they have a right to say no. It'd just be the law of the land, not just for Facebook, for - but for any of these online companies. This is the moment of reckoning.

SAM SANDERS: Moment of reckoning. Do you buy that, Alina?

ALINA SELYUKH: I kind of do. I don't know...

SAM SANDERS: OK.

ALINA SELYUKH: ...Where it will take us. I think this is a moment that a lot of regular people can understand in terms of privacy conversations. People feel very connected to their own personas online. There's a big push by some advocates to bring those European laws to the U.S. - this kind of forceful opt-in requirement on Internet companies. The FTC is investigating Facebook yet again.

VANESSA ROMO: Right.

ALINA SELYUKH: So the outcome of that investigation may or may not come to light eventually, may or may not result in some kind of change. I find it really hard to imagine how Facebook pivots and changes their business model, as we talked about - this concept that their money comes from advertising, which relies on the data that it collects about you. So I'm not really sure. I'm not really sure this is...

SAM SANDERS: Yeah.

ALINA SELYUKH: ...Like, a peak in a valley. I don't know. (Laughter) I don't know.

VANESSA ROMO: I started off feeling, like, comforted by you.

ALINA SELYUKH: I just...

SAM SANDERS: (Laughter).

VANESSA ROMO: But then but the end, I'm still as scared as I was before this conversation started.

(SOUNDBITE OF FLEVANS' "FLICKER")

SAM SANDERS: So basically, this story has legs. It won't go away. We'll probably check in with you again very soon, Alina, because the Internet, more than ever, is a scary place.

ALINA SELYUKH: On that dark note...

(LAUGHTER)

SAM SANDERS: On that dark note, we're going to go to a break. When we come back, we'll play a really fun uplifting game called Who Said That. This is IT'S BEEN A MINUTE from NPR.

(SOUNDBITE OF FLEVANS' "FLICKER")

SAM SANDERS: You're listening to IT'S BEEN A MINUTE from NPR, the show where we catch up on the week that was. I'm Sam Sanders here with two guests, Vanessa Romo and Alina Selyukh, both reporters for NPR, with me today.

ALINA SELYUKH: Hi.

VANESSA ROMO: Hey there.

SAM SANDERS: It is time, you guys, for my favorite, favorite game.

(SOUNDBITE OF TV SHOW, "THE REAL HOUSEWIVES OF ATLANTA")

KANDI BURRUSS: Who had been saying that?

PORSHA WILLIAMS: Who said that?

KENYA MOORE: Who said that?

ALINA SELYUKH: This is my redemption tour.

(LAUGHTER)

SAM SANDERS: What'd you do, lose last time?

ALINA SELYUKH: Oh, severely.

(LAUGHTER)

SAM SANDERS: So the game is very simple. I share a quote from the week. You guys have to guess Who Said That or at least get close, guess the story, guess a key word. We're not sticklers here. The thing is, though, the winner gets absolutely nothing. You guys ready?

ALINA SELYUKH: And the loser gets to come back again, right? Right? Right?

VANESSA ROMO: (Laughter).

SAM SANDERS: Yes. Yes. You can always play again. This is the best game because of that reason. You guys ready?

VANESSA ROMO: Let's do this.

ALINA SELYUKH: Sure.

SAM SANDERS: All right. Here's the first quote. I really do love this one. "Them little tweets don't faze me. McDonald's be so lazy. I know the reason you hating me - because I'm fast food's first lady."

ALINA SELYUKH: It has to be Wendy's.

(SOUNDBITE OF VICTORY TUNE)

SAM SANDERS: Yes.

ALINA SELYUKH: I don't know the story.

VANESSA ROMO: So good.

ALINA SELYUKH: But it has to be Wendy's.

SAM SANDERS: So Wendy's just released a mixtape...

ALINA SELYUKH: What?

VANESSA ROMO: Oh, goodness.

SAM SANDERS: ...Full of a woman rapper, like, dissing McDonald's and Burger King.

ALINA SELYUKH: (Laughter).

SAM SANDERS: The songs are hilarious. The production is actually pretty top-notch. And there's one song off the mixtape "Rest In Grease" that is just...

VANESSA ROMO: Oh.

SAM SANDERS: ...Hot fire.

(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, "REST IN GREASE")

UNIDENTIFIED ARTIST: (Rapping) It's Queen Wendy up in this thing. Y'all can't beat us serving these things. Y'all too chicken for this beef.

ALINA SELYUKH: No.

(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, "REST IN GREASE")

UNIDENTIFIED ARTIST: (Rapping) I'm going to leave you resting in grease.

ALINA SELYUKH: I want to be in that corporate meeting where somebody says, guys...

VANESSA ROMO: What was the casting process for this like?

ALINA SELYUKH: ...I know what we're going to do.

SAM SANDERS: I have no idea. This Wendy's mixtape hit No. 3...

VANESSA ROMO: No.

SAM SANDERS: ...On the iTunes Hip-Hop charts recently.

VANESSA ROMO: No. No.

ALINA SELYUKH: I'm not surprised.

SAM SANDERS: It's for real.

VANESSA ROMO: There are no rules to anything anymore, right? I know I sound like a really old person saying that. But, like...

SAM SANDERS: It's true.

VANESSA ROMO: ...Nothing means anything anymore.

SAM SANDERS: Here's the thing. Yeah, there are no rules. There is just content.

ALINA SELYUKH: Content.

SAM SANDERS: Alina, you're up one.

ALINA SELYUKH: What, what.

SAM SANDERS: Time for the next quote. You ready?

VANESSA ROMO: Yes.

SAM SANDERS: "They joke that the president and Congress are all clowns. Well, in my professional opinion, they are the worst clowns I've ever seen." Who said that?

ALINA SELYUKH: Some clown - professional clown?

SAM SANDERS: That's actually right.

(SOUNDBITE OF VICTORY TUNE)

VANESSA ROMO: What?

SAM SANDERS: I'm just going to give it to you. This is a former clown named Steve Lough.

VANESSA ROMO: A no-longer-practicing clown?

SAM SANDERS: No-longer-practicing clown. He used to work for Ringling Brothers Circus. Now he's running for Congress as a Democrat in South Carolina's 5th district.

ALINA SELYUKH: Oh, oh.

SAM SANDERS: Can I tell you his website?

VANESSA ROMO: Yeah.

SAM SANDERS: His website is clownforcongress.com.

VANESSA ROMO: No.

SAM SANDERS: Right? So we've been hearing for months now that there is this coming blue wave in the November midterms where all of these Dems and left folks who are energized are running for office. And the numbers apparently are astronomical. That's probably true because even the clowns are running for office.

VANESSA ROMO: So when he says they're all clowns, it's a good thing in his opinion.

SAM SANDERS: Maybe.

VANESSA ROMO: Because he's a clown for Congress. I mean, how does this add up?

SAM SANDERS: You can go to clownforcongress.com and find all about it.

ALINA SELYUKH: Learn all about it.

SAM SANDERS: Learn all about it. Yeah.

VANESSA ROMO: And then Facebook will track it forever.

ALINA SELYUKH: I won't be advertised to. It's all good.

SAM SANDERS: Ready for the last quote?

VANESSA ROMO: Yes.

SAM SANDERS: Quote, "I would like to thank my writers, all liberals. It has been fun to talk with you and jam. You are all wonderful." Who said that? It was a reboot of a thing that was very popular in the culture in the '90s. It came back in...

VANESSA ROMO: "Roseanne."

(SOUNDBITE OF VICTORY TUNE)

SAM SANDERS: Yeah, Vanessa.

VANESSA ROMO: I got one.

SAM SANDERS: You got one. So "Roseanne" - her show came back to TV this week. The premiere was watched by about 18 million people.

VANESSA ROMO: Yeah. Huge ratings. Huge ratings.

SAM SANDERS: Huge ratings. It was so big, Donald Trump called her to congratulate her because...

VANESSA ROMO: That's right.

ALINA SELYUKH: What?

SAM SANDERS: ...The whole premise of "Roseanne" this time is that they are a family of Trump supporters.

VANESSA ROMO: Or a divided family.

SAM SANDERS: OK.

VANESSA ROMO: They're not all - Roseanne is a Trump supporter.

SAM SANDERS: Yes. Yes.

VANESSA ROMO: I watched a little trailer.

SAM SANDERS: Did you enjoy it?

VANESSA ROMO: You know what? I loved "Roseanne" when I was a kid.

SAM SANDERS: Same.

VANESSA ROMO: I loved that show. I thought it was, like, a really great show about, like, working-class families and just kind of a great depiction of the way that normal people lived, which was a great contrast to everything else that was on TV at the time. Yeah. And, you know, yes, as you mentioned, Trump found the time to pick up the phone. And I think he may have also tweeted about it, which, you know...

SAM SANDERS: Wow. So the game is over. Alina, I think you won.

ALINA SELYUKH: How are we not talking about Beyonce yet?

SAM SANDERS: Wait for it.

VANESSA ROMO: Oh.

SAM SANDERS: This is our bonus quote. I was going to give you - I was going to make one of the Who Said That quotes this week all about Beyonce. But you already know what that is.

ALINA SELYUKH: It was already...

SAM SANDERS: So we'll just give you a little bonus and say my favorite quote of the week was this. Quote, "Near the end of the party, Beyonce's at the bar. So I said to Beyonce, did she really bite you?"

VANESSA ROMO: (Laughter).

SAM SANDERS: That, of course, was Tiffany Haddish, my favorite comic of the moment. In a GQ profile, she describes this party scene in which an unnamed actress bites Beyonce, leading Tiffany to want to confront the actress and fight her. Beyonce says, no. Don't do it. Don't do it.

VANESSA ROMO: She's on drugs.

SAM SANDERS: But since this has been revealed, we have all been trying to figure out #WhoBitBeyonce.

ALINA SELYUKH: Did you see what Tiffany had to say...

SAM SANDERS: No. What'd she say?

ALINA SELYUKH: ...Yesterday or a couple of days ago when she was asked about this one more time? Well, first, she said, NDAs are real. Stop asking me about this.

VANESSA ROMO: Oh, wow.

SAM SANDERS: (Laughter).

ALINA SELYUKH: ...And then proceeded to say that there are a lot more important things to worry about. For example, have you done your taxes yet?

VANESSA ROMO: (Laughter).

ALINA SELYUKH: They're due real soon.

SAM SANDERS: Tiffany - you know what, though? Tiffany, as much as I love her, she stepped in it. You can't bring that up and not expect the entire world...

VANESSA ROMO: It's unfair.

ALINA SELYUKH: It's been great.

SAM SANDERS: Listeners, if you know, let us know. I will tell you, though, no one's biting over here. But the clear winner of the game is Alina. You won Who Said That. Congratulations.

ALINA SELYUKH: Yes.

VANESSA ROMO: (Laughter).

SAM SANDERS: So how's it feel?

ALINA SELYUKH: I feel redeemed.

VANESSA ROMO: Uh-huh.

SAM SANDERS: OK.

ALINA SELYUKH: I feel redeemed.

SAM SANDERS: All right.

VANESSA ROMO: She's glowing.

SAM SANDERS: Well, you get that and nothing else because there is no prize.

ALINA SELYUKH: That's all right.

SAM SANDERS: Now it's time to end the show as we always do. We ask our listeners every week to share with us the best thing that happened to them all week. We encourage folks to brag. They do. Let's take a listen.

TINA: Hi, Sam. This is Tina (ph) calling from Michigan, and the best thing that happened to me this week is that I got my first flock of 25 baby chickens.

SAM SANDERS: Wow.

VANESSA ROMO: Twenty five?

SAM SANDERS: That's a lot.

AMY: Hey, Sam. This is Amy (ph) in San Diego, and the best thing that happened to me this week was marrying my boyfriend of eight years on a beach in Belize.

SAM SANDERS: Congrats.

KELSEY: My husband and I took eight whole days off of work and went to Paris, France.

ALINA SELYUKH: Amazing.

SAM SANDERS: Wow.

CHRISTOPHER: I ran my 16th half-marathon today.

SAM SANDERS: Congrats.

EMILY: After 11 years, I submitted my Ph.D. thesis to be examined.

AUSTIN: Hey, Sam. This is Austin (ph) from Long Beach, Calif. Best thing that happened to me this week was I managed to get in as a VIP guest of Travis Barker...

SAM SANDERS: Whoa.

AUSTIN: ...At a Blink-182 show.

ALINA SELYUKH: Amazing.

VANESSA ROMO: (Laughter).

SAM SANDERS: Blink-182.

MAYA: Hi, Sam. This is Maya (ph) from Chennai, India. And the best thing that happened to me this week was that I graduated high school as the valedictorian.

SAM SANDERS: Congratulations.

MAYA: And I gave a speech that made a bunch of people cry.

SAM SANDERS: Oh.

JOE: Hey, Sam. It's Joe from Greenfield, Mass., but I'm - right, now I'm in Brooklyn, N.Y. because after many months of not getting any work as a makeup artist or makeup designer...

SAM SANDERS: Uh-huh.

JOE: I found out about a month ago I would be designing "Jesus Christ Superstar Live" on NBC.

SAM SANDERS: Wow.

ALINA SELYUKH: What?

JOE: And right now, I am walking in, and we are doing camera tests.

SAM SANDERS: Wow.

JOE: And yeah, it's been kind of incredible.

ALINA SELYUKH: Good luck.

SAM SANDERS: Congratulations, man.

LAURA: Hi, Sam. This is Laura (ph) from Centerville, Utah. The best thing that happened to me this week was on Sunday, when I got the results from my ancestry DNA test. I was adopted at birth, and I have never connected with my birth family. And when I got my DNA results, I matched with a sister, and so I have been emailing...

ALINA SELYUKH: What?

LAURA: ...With my birth sister...

VANESSA ROMO: Crazy.

SAM SANDERS: Woah.

LAURA: For the beginning of this weekend, it's been pretty awesome.

SAM SANDERS: So cool.

ALINA SELYUKH: That's amazing.

PAMELA: Hi, Sam. This is Pamela (ph) calling from Vermont. About a year ago, my 16-year-old daughter was diagnosed with cancer. And it was right around the time that your show started airing. And we have spent the year mainly in the hospital, and I've listened to every one of your shows since it started. The best thing that happened to me this week was my daughter is officially done with her chemotherapy treatment...

SAM SANDERS: Good, good, good.

PAMELA: ...And cancer-free.

SAM SANDERS: Oh, man.

ALINA SELYUKH: What?

SAM SANDERS: That's great news.

PAMELA: So I just wanted to say thanks for being there this year, and take care.

VANESSA ROMO: Oh, that's amazing.

SAM SANDERS: Oh, man.

ALINA SELYUKH: Congratulations.

PAMELA: Ok, thanks.

AUSTIN: Have a great day, Sam.

KELSEY: Thanks.

JOE: Bye.

SAM SANDERS: Thanks to all the voices you heard there - Tina with the 25 chickens...

ALINA SELYUKH: Amazing.

SAM SANDERS: ...Amy, Kelsey (ph), Christopher (ph), Emily (ph), Austin at the Blink-182 concert.

VANESSA ROMO: (Laughter).

SAM SANDERS: Maya, congrats on being valedictorian. Joe, good luck with your show on NBC. Laura and Pamela, thank you for sharing that story. I'm so glad your daughter is cancer-free, and I am honored that we could be a part of your last year or so. We listen to all of these that come in. Keep them coming along with the dog pics, cat pics and soon to be 25 chicken pics.

ALINA SELYUKH: Can I throw in my brag?

SAM SANDERS: Yeah.

ALINA SELYUKH: My cat turned 1.

SAM SANDERS: Oh (clapping).

ALINA SELYUKH: And I made him wear a tiny cape.

VANESSA ROMO: (Laughter).

ALINA SELYUKH: It was wonderful.

SAM SANDERS: Send us pictures.

ALINA SELYUKH: He is Instagram famous.

SAM SANDERS: Oh, yeah. Oh, yeah. You can always let us know the best parts of your week any week. Just email me at samsanders@npr.org - samsanders@npr.org With that, a special thanks again to my guests for this show, Vanessa Romo and Alina Selyukh, two wonderful reporters at NPR. And as always and forever, special thanks to Britney Spears for giving us gems like these.

ALINA SELYUKH: I'm so happy to be here this week for this.

SAM SANDERS: I guess we can say...

VANESSA ROMO: We did it again.

SAM SANDERS: ...At this point, we did it again.

ALINA SELYUKH: We did it again.

VANESSA ROMO: We did it again.

SAM SANDERS: ...With this show, right? This week, the show was produced by Brent Baughman and Anjuli Sastry with some help from Tom Dreisbach. Our director of programming is Steve Nelson. And we were edited this week by Uri Berliner. Our big boss who signs the checks is Anya Grundmann, NPR's VP of programming.

And before we go, got a quick correction from last week's episode. We talked about sanctuary cities and mentioned the town of Los Alamitos in California. Los Alamitos is not in Los Angeles County. It's actually in neighboring Orange County. Thanks to our attentive California listeners for pointing that out.

Refresh your feed Tuesday morning. I have a chat with the Oscar-winning actor Tim Robbins. He has a new show on HBO called "Here And Now." But we also talk about one of the best films of all time that he was in, "The Shawshank Redemption." That'll be in your feed Tuesday morning.

Also, I asked you last week. I'm going to ask you again. If you liked this show, put a rating on the show. Go to iTunes. Rate us. It just helps folks find it. Thanks for listening. Next week, we'll do it again. I'm Sam Sanders. Talk soon.

(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, "OOPS!... I DID IT AGAIN")

BRITNEY SPEARS: (Singing) But to lose all my senses, that is just so typically me. Oh, baby. Oh, oops, I did it again.

Is the sustainability "bubble" ready to pop on Wall Street? Should PR share the blame for the growing price gap between social responsibility stocks and other equities?

Morningstar found that investors poured $21B into environmental, social and governance funds in 2019, just about quadrupling the 2018 amount.

Savita Subramanian, Bank of America's head of US equity strategy, said the "monstrous" inflow of money into ESG funds is driving the valuation gap, according to the Financial Times.

Some Wall Streeters believe ESG stocks are on fire because corporate CEOs heed PR messaging about meeting the needs of all stakeholders including employees, customers, communities and society as a whole.

The FT noted that money flowing into energy renewable stocks comes at the expense of oil & gas companies.

"There appears to be a growing disconnect between operational performance and share price returns," said Eugene Klerk, head of global ESG research at Credit Suisse. "There is a growing awareness or nervousness around this particular topic."

Morgan Stanley reports the outperformance of ESG stocks began six to nine months ago and that it typically takes at least five years before overheated sectors cool down. That means there's still plenty of time for corporate CEOs to buy into PR's ESG pitch.

Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg penned a Feb. 16 op-ed in the Financial Times that called for more regulation of Big Tech because he doesn't think "private companies should make so many decisions alone when they touch on fundamental democratic values."

The article was a smokescreen, a PR ploy to get Facebook off the hook. Since the US government moves at a glacial speed, there's no way regulatory safeguards could be erected in time for the 2020 election.

Zuckerberg could snap his fingers and kill political advertising tomorrow, if he wished.

Philanthropist George Soros noted in a Feb. 18 letter-to-the-editor piece published in the FT that if FB has any "doubt whether an ad is political, it should err on the side of caution and refuse to publish."

Soros doubts that going to happen because he believes Zuckerberg is "engaged in some kind of mutual assistance arrangement with Donald Trump that will help him to get re-elected."

The Trump campaign has hired Matt Oczkowski, who was head of product at Cambridge Analytica, the data firm that improperly obtained the personal information of tens of millions of FB users.

Oczkowski played a key role in Project Alamo, the online campaign orchestrated through FB advertising that helped put Trump in the White House.

What do you say, Mark? There's still time to pull the plug on political advertising.

Twitter feels heat on global warming. While Facebook is taking hits for its policies on political advertising, Twitter deserves scrutiny for running tweets denying global warming that are produced by bots.

A quarter of all climate crisis tweets stem from bots, according to a not-yet-published study from Brown University. The Guardian of the UK obtained a draft of the report. The Brown researchers found the bots had a "substantial impact" in amplifying global denial messaging and building support for president Trump's decision to withdraw from the Paris climate agreement.

Stephan Lewandowsky, co-author of the study that analyzed 6.5M tweets, isn't surprised at the global denial messages. "More often than not, they turn out to have all the fingerprints of bots," he told The Guardian. "The more denial trolls are out there the more likely people will think that there is a diversity of opinion and hence will weaken their support for climate science."

What do you say, Twitter?

You've got to tip your hat to president Trump. He's a master at stagecraft. His Feb. 16 appearance at the Daytona 500 was pure magic. It was the opposite of a helmeted Mike Dukakis awkwardly sitting in a tank.

Flying from Mar-a-Lago, Air Force One did a lap above the Daytona International Speedway track before landing across the street at Daytona International Airport.

Air Force Thunderbirds, which did two fly-overs of the track, were parked next to the presidential plane.

Trump's motorcade then led a parade of racing cars around the 2.5-mile track. With First Lady Melania Trump at his side, the president gave a short pep talk before closing with, "Rubber will burn, fans will scream, and the great American race will begin." As grand marshal, he declared, "Gentlemen, start your engines."

The crowd loved every minute of it and took up chants of "USA," "four more years," and "we love you."

White House media organ Fox News broadcast the spectacle and the Trump campaign filed an ad of the event. The Daytona Beach News-Journal reported that Trump's visit would be long remembered by Trump's fans.

The only glitch: Campaign manager Brad Parscale tweeted that Trump won the Daytona 500 even before the race started. Unfortunately, he accompanied the tweet with a 2004 image of Air Force One carrying George W. Bush, taking off from Daytona after he attended the race.

Parscale deleted that image, which featured more fans in the stands than there were at this year's opening of the NASCAR season.

Photo, Savita Subramanian

urn:contentItem:5W9S-MT71-DY1J-T049-00000-00No Headline In Original2019-06-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:13:50ZLexisNexisIt's Been A Minute With Sam Sanders12:00 AM ESTKelsey SnellSam SandersAunt BettyAunt DonnaCeline DionTony RommJane CoastonKandi BurrussPorsha WilliamsIan DoescherMaggie RineyMelindaJasmineSamantha

AUNT BETTY: Hey, y'all. This is Sam's Aunt Betty.

AUNT DONNA: And Sam's Aunt Donna on the West Coast.

AUNT BETTY: This week on the show, Washington Post technology reporter Tony Romm.

AUNT DONNA: And NPR congressional correspondent Kelsey Snell. All right. Let's start the show.

AUNT BETTY: All right. Let's start the show.

(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, "THAT'S THE WAY IT IS")

CELINE DION: (Singing) Yeah.

SAM SANDERS: Hey, y'all. From NPR, I'm Sam Sanders. IT'S BEEN A MINUTE.

KELSEY SNELL: That was great.

TONY ROMM: (Laughter).

SAM SANDERS: Double the aunties. So Aunt Betty came to California to visit me and other relatives.

KELSEY SNELL: I saw the pictures. Did she bring treats to the whole newsroom?

SAM SANDERS: She brought a pound cake to NPR West.

TONY ROMM: What?

KELSEY SNELL: (Laughter).

SAM SANDERS: She was a hit. And then she went to visit my other aunt, Donna, in San Diego. And they both announced you this week. It was really sweet.

KELSEY SNELL: Aw.

SAM SANDERS: I know. I know. Speaking of sweet things, (laughter), happy weekend to our listeners and to my guests, Tony Romm, reporter at The Washington Post covering technology policy, and Kelsey Snell, who covers Congress for NPR. Both of you are old friends. I'm happy to have all of this friendship in studio with me.

KELSEY SNELL: Very exciting.

TONY ROMM: Why we got to be old? Why we got to be old?

(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, "THAT'S THE WAY IT IS")

CELINE DION: (Singing) When you want it the most, there's no easy way out.

SAM SANDERS: Speaking of forever young, we're joined this week by the voice of Celine Dion.

KELSEY SNELL: I know. I've been dancing over here.

SAM SANDERS: As you should be. Pump it up.

TONY ROMM: (Laughter).

(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, "THAT'S THE WAY IT IS")

CELINE DION: (Singing) Love comes to those who believe it, and that's the way it is.

SAM SANDERS: This is a Celine Dion classic, "That's The Way It Is." And I'm playing it this week to honor her as her long, long run with her Las Vegas residency comes to a close.

TONY ROMM: Wow.

SAM SANDERS: This weekend, it ends. Her last show at The Colosseum at Caesars Palace will happen this weekend. And did you guys know that she first went to Vegas in 2003?

KELSEY SNELL: I was just going to ask. It's been a long time.

TONY ROMM: Right.

SAM SANDERS: Yeah. So she began 16 years ago. She's basically been doing the same job for 13 of those 16 years.

KELSEY SNELL: Holy cow.

SAM SANDERS: And she really changed the way that artists handle touring and their careers by doing what she did. So when Celine first went to Vegas in '03, no one was doing it. Like, the big headliners were, like, Tom Jones.

KELSEY SNELL: Really?

SAM SANDERS: But Celine went and was really successful, and she made it a cool thing to do. And so now everyone goes to Vegas. I'm sure you know this.

KELSEY SNELL: Yeah. Like, Britney's there, right?

SAM SANDERS: Yeah. Britney's there. Gaga was there. J.Lo, Boyz II Men, Toni Braxton, Mariah Carey, Drake, Janet Jackson. Everyone does it now, and Celine Dion made that happen.

KELSEY SNELL: I mean, it's, like, a quick flight, right, from LA to go out there and perform? So if you lived in LA, you could, like, have a pretty humane life instead of traveling all over the world.

SAM SANDERS: Exactly. And so that is a thing that artists love. You can have the crowds come to you in Vegas and not have to travel the country or the world for them. And also, as the industry has changed in the last 10 years or so with the rise of streaming, all of them sell less albums, and so their money is in playing shows for people.

(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, "THAT'S THE WAY IT IS")

CELINE DION: (Singing) When you want it the most...

SAM SANDERS: And so Celine made this model that is really easy and really lucrative if you're big enough. And, like, she changed the game.

KELSEY SNELL: Well, cheers to Celine.

TONY ROMM: Right?

SAM SANDERS: Celine, kudos to you.

TONY ROMM: (Laughter).

SAM SANDERS: I'll miss your show. It was nice just knowing that she was there.

KELSEY SNELL: But your heart will go on.

SAM SANDERS: (Laughter). Yes, it will. It will, it will.

TONY ROMM: (Laughter).

(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, "THAT'S THE WAY IT IS")

CELINE DION: (Singing) And that's the way it is.

SAM SANDERS: You can check out Kevin Fallon's story in The Daily Beast this week. It's all about Celine Dion and her exit from Vegas. All right. Now it's time to start the show as we always do. We ask each of our guests to describe their week of news in only three words. But all of our three words are going to focus on one big news story of the week. I am talking about the potential regulation of big tech companies. The Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission have both taken early steps to investigate Google and Apple and Facebook and Amazon. And lawmakers in the House in D.C., they plan to look into Facebook and Google and other tech companies to see if they're too big.

So Kelsey, Tony, you're both covering this this week. And I want you to give me three words on this topic. But first, both of you, catch me up. Catch us up on what all happened this week 'cause it seemed like a lot of things came together at once.

TONY ROMM: Yeah. A lot of things did come together all at once. But it's sort of been simmering for a long time now, right? Like, people are just sort of generally annoyed with Facebook, which is, like, the Exxon Valdez of the tech industry...

SAM SANDERS: (Laughter).

KELSEY SNELL: (Laughter).

TONY ROMM: ...With some of these other companies, like Google and Amazon and Apple and so forth, for various reasons, too. But really, there were two chunks of news. The first was that we finally got word that the Federal Trade Commission and the Department of Justice have essentially divvied up oversight of these tech companies on antitrust grounds.

KELSEY SNELL: And at the same time, Congress decided that they want to start having a conversation that they've essentially been avoiding entirely for decades.

SAM SANDERS: Yeah.

TONY ROMM: Like most things.

KELSEY SNELL: Right (laughter).

SAM SANDERS: (Laughter).

KELSEY SNELL: And it's always a little surprising when Congress actually volunteers to begin a process of looking into something they actively don't want to look into, like tech. So it's just been kind of one of those weeks where the worlds are kind of colliding and kind of all surrounding tech.

SAM SANDERS: I want us to break down what these investigators and what these agencies mean when they talk about antitrust, this idea that these companies are too big and that they should possibly be, like, broken up. What are the things that could be broken up, and what reasons do folks have to say they've become too big?

TONY ROMM: Right. I mean, it takes many forms. It kind - and it depends on the company you're talking about. So Google is the company that's come up in this conversation most. And the Europeans have sort of sketched out what this looks like. The company has been under fire for giving preferential treatment to its services over rivals in search results. So, you know, you'll go type in whatever, and Google's version of that product will come up before its competitors, which folks in Europe saw as a major issue. And they fined the crap out of Google for having done it because people don't click to, like, the third page at Google. So like, why...

SAM SANDERS: I do.

TONY ROMM: Do you?

SAM SANDERS: Yeah, because I know that they're going to give me all their stuff first.

TONY ROMM: Yeah. Well, there you go. So...

(LAUGHTER)

TONY ROMM: So like...

SAM SANDERS: I'm an outlier.

TONY ROMM: Right. So for Google, it's stuff like that and the fact that they're just buying up all these competitors. For Facebook, it's the reality that there really is, I think in the eyes of most consumers, like, one social network. And then people say, oh, well, you know, let's just go use Instagram instead of Facebook. Well, Instagram is owned by Facebook. The feds let Facebook buy Instagram. It's, like, that kind of stuff that's really on the minds of folks here. Like, whether - like, was all that good for the country, for the economy, for people?

SAM SANDERS: Was there a thing that one of these companies did that made everyone say, this is the week? Or it was just kind of about that time.

TONY ROMM: It was really the latter. The Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission had been talking about this for quite a long time, and we really only got word of exactly how they were going to break this stuff down with respect to potential investigations over the weekend. That was sort of a coincidence, I would say. With respect to the House, again, lawmakers there have been talking about some sort of antitrust probe for a bit, but I think they sort of sensed the momentum - the political momentum. And that's why we saw the announcements.

KELSEY SNELL: Yeah, I would say that there was a lot of pressure from the 2020 candidates - Democrats running for president - who are starting to talk about this in a more direct way. Particularly, Elizabeth Warren is talking about it a lot. And...

SAM SANDERS: Does she have a plan for that?

KELSEY SNELL: Not really.

TONY ROMM: She's got a medium post.

KELSEY SNELL: Yeah.

(LAUGHTER)

TONY ROMM: I didn't mean that to be as shady as it sounded.

(LAUGHTER)

SAM SANDERS: Whenever you say medium post, it's shady.

(LAUGHTER)

KELSEY SNELL: But, I mean, just the fact that 2020 candidates and viable 2020 candidates are talking about it, we're going to see that push Democrats...

SAM SANDERS: Yeah.

KELSEY SNELL: ...In Congress to take action anyway because that's kind of the way things work.

SAM SANDERS: Yeah. So we're all caught up now on what exactly happened. Kelsey, you have three words on this news topic. What are they?

KELSEY SNELL: Yes, my three words are OK, now what?

(LAUGHTER)

KELSEY SNELL: So...

SAM SANDERS: Wait. Referee, umpire, is OK one word? It's one word.

KELSEY SNELL: (Laughter).

TONY ROMM: Ooh.

SAM SANDERS: It's two letters.

KELSEY SNELL: Oh, yeah, I was going - I - when I wrote it out...

TONY ROMM: O-K-A-Y.

KELSEY SNELL: ...It was just OK.

SAM SANDERS: OK...

KELSEY SNELL: (Laughter).

SAM SANDERS: ...With an O-K-A-Y. OK, perfect.

KELSEY SNELL: Yeah.

SAM SANDERS: OK, now what? Go ahead.

KELSEY SNELL: So the reason I ask that is Congress says they want to do something, but doing something could mean a whole lot of things. Do they want to actually regulate? Do they want to break up the tech companies? Do they want to go back to ignoring the tech companies? Are they going to think better of this once they realize that tech companies give them a lot of money...

(LAUGHTER)

KELSEY SNELL: ...And employ a lot of people all over the country?

SAM SANDERS: Yeah.

KELSEY SNELL: This is a really vague conversation that we're having. And I hate the word conversation in general because the word is vague. But that's where we are...

(LAUGHTER)

SAM SANDERS: Yeah.

KELSEY SNELL: ...Is - nobody has really been able to identify what it is they want to do. They just are acknowledging a problem. And I would say in this conversation, Tony is definitely the expert on the policy that happens. And I'm the expert on Congress not really doing anything. And...

(LAUGHTER)

KELSEY SNELL: In this case, I want to see what they're actually going to do before I start to have a really strong sense of where things are going.

SAM SANDERS: Yeah. Yeah. So, Tony, what are your three words?

TONY ROMM: Yeah, my three words are one more thing, which...

SAM SANDERS: OK.

KELSEY SNELL: (Laughter).

TONY ROMM: ...Y'all might remember is the thing that Steve Jobs used to say when he, you know, was unveiling iPhones and people would fangirl...

SAM SANDERS: Oh...

TONY ROMM: ...During the iPhones...

SAM SANDERS: ...Yeah.

TONY ROMM: And there would be something else that they would have. But one more thing doesn't just describe that. I think it actually just describes where the tech industry is right now, politically speaking. Kelsey kind of alluded to some of this. It's not just antitrust and these concerns about bigness and what bigness means for competition and consumers. It's also disinformation. It's privacy. It's YouTube not doing enough to take down hate speech, which we saw play out over the course of this week, as, once again, the company was under fire for failing to act fast enough to take down repulsive stuff online.

And I think for a while, if you talked to a lot of these companies, what they would tell you is, this is just a blip, right? It's people in Washington doing Washington things, just getting really loud about stuff because it generates headlines. And eventually, it'll blow over. But the reality is that that's not the case. Like, people here are frustrated with the industry. The conversation has only gotten louder in the course of the past year or two. And it's a marked change from where we were 10 years ago when I was covering this stuff, when tech was, like, the darling of everybody here. You could do no wrong. And now I think the threats are serious. So, you know, to Kelsey's point - now what? Like, we'll see if Congress actually does something with this. But the conditions, the pieces are there for some serious regulations targeting the tech industry.

SAM SANDERS: Yeah. I wonder if the GOP has precedent to possibly pursue this kind of stuff because when you think about the government breaking up big corporations, you don't think of the Republican Party wanting to do that. Could they be a part of that now?

KELSEY SNELL: Well, they're - I mean, that's a tough question at this point because we don't know how much the Senate is engaging on it. They aren't engaging as much as the House is. And the House is, frankly, run by Democrats.

SAM SANDERS: Yeah.

TONY ROMM: Yeah. That being said, the Republicans are going after the tech industry for a much different reason than the Democrats are.

KELSEY SNELL: Yeah.

TONY ROMM: And you hear this come up in a lot with the conversation around anti-conservative bias.

SAM SANDERS: Oh, yeah.

TONY ROMM: There are all these Republicans, right up to the president, who say that Facebook and Google and whatnot limit the reach of conservatives and delete their content to make it harder for them to reach folks, even though the president has - what? - like, 60 million followers or something on Twitter right now.

SAM SANDERS: Yeah.

TONY ROMM: And so they use that as an attack vector against these companies to say that they've become too powerful. It's much different than the Democrats, which are out there talking about corporate power in a different capacity.

SAM SANDERS: Yeah, which brings us to my three words, which are about that issue of speech. My three words on this whole tech debate are Section 230.

TONY ROMM: (Laughter) Is that three words?

SAM SANDERS: Yeah.

(LAUGHTER)

SAM SANDERS: Section T-W-O T-H-I-R-T-Y.

(LAUGHTER)

KELSEY SNELL: Very technical (laughter).

SAM SANDERS: I am obsessed with varying interpretations of this section of the Communications Decency Act - Section 230. It says, basically, two things. One, tech companies can't really be sued for what other people do on their platforms. And two, it gives these companies the right to censor content and to kick people off their platforms if they want. But the left and the right have very differing interpretations of this law. Tony, how confusing is this?

TONY ROMM: You know, it - on some level, it's kind of not. The government...

SAM SANDERS: OK.

TONY ROMM: ...Said tech platforms, like a Facebook or whatnot, should not be held liable for the content posted by their users. And the effects of that are twofold. First, it allowed the development of services that accept user-generated content, like photos and videos or whatnot and - without which the tech companies say they never would have offered social networks because they would have faced too many lawsuits. It would've been impossible in the early days of the Web. And the second is that it gave those companies the power to enforce their own terms of service without facing additional lawsuits and stuff.

SAM SANDERS: Yeah.

TONY ROMM: So there's a lot of misconceptions about 230 on Capitol Hill, but there's this feeling that, like, something is busted, right? Like, when videos of white supremacy go viral on YouTube, when hate speech and anti-Semitism goes viral on Twitter, when attack videos from the two Christchurch mosques in New Zealand go viral on the Web, you know, those companies face no repercussions for that outside the court of public opinion here in the United States. And to a lot of lawmakers and to a lot of regular users, that's just fundamentally wrong.

KELSEY SNELL: Well - and that's part of what has gotten the attention of Democrats in the House too is that - Nancy Pelosi was actually just on the radio in California, talking about how she thinks it's unacceptable that Facebook wouldn't take down a video that was doctored to make her look drunk.

SAM SANDERS: Oh, yeah.

KELSEY SNELL: And there were people inside of the president's circle who were retweeting this and spreading it.

TONY ROMM: Right.

KELSEY SNELL: And Pelosi basically said we let Facebook just kind of get a pass for too long.

SAM SANDERS: Yeah. What I find so fascinating is that the very politicians who are railing against a company like Facebook, saying, get it together; they still have to use Facebook...

TONY ROMM: They're using it.

SAM SANDERS: ...To reach their constituents.

TONY ROMM: It's true. And my favorite story of this week is Ted Cruz is out there, you know, making some noise again this week about how conservatives are being biased on Facebook. Ted Cruz is also running ads on Facebook pointing out his fight...

SAM SANDERS: (Laughter).

TONY ROMM: ...About anti-conservative bias. Like, literally, he's raising money using the tool that he claims is not allowing him to, like, reach conservative voters. And...

SAM SANDERS: Oy.

TONY ROMM: He's not the only one who's been doing something like this.

SAM SANDERS: Oh, yeah.

(SOUNDBITE OF FLEVANS' "FLICKER")

SAM SANDERS: Time for a break. You're listening to IT'S BEEN A MINUTE from NPR. Coming up, we're going to talk about a word that everyone seems to be using but few folks actually get right - intersectionality. It is loved by the left, hated by the right. We'll tell you why after the break. You're listening to IT'S BEEN A MINUTE from NPR. We'll be right back.

(SOUNDBITE OF FLEVANS' "FLICKER")

SAM SANDERS: We're back. You're listening to IT'S BEEN A MINUTE from NPR, the show where we catch up on the week that was. I'm Sam Sanders here with two guests - Tony Romm, who covers tech policy at The Washington Post, and Kelsey Snell, who covers Congress for NPR. Do either of you use AirDrop?

KELSEY SNELL: I don't. I turn it off...

TONY ROMM: Oh, no.

KELSEY SNELL: ...On my phone.

TONY ROMM: No, I turned it off because I know exactly where this is going.

KELSEY SNELL: Yeah.

SAM SANDERS: Yeah.

TONY ROMM: (Laughter).

SAM SANDERS: So tell folks who don't know yet what AirDrop is and how it works.

KELSEY SNELL: AirDrop allows somebody to move something from their phone to any phone that they can see, essentially, right around them, right...

TONY ROMM: Yeah.

KELSEY SNELL: ...Tony?

TONY ROMM: Yeah, you have to have an iPhone to do it...

KELSEY SNELL: Right.

TONY ROMM: ...Or an Apple device to do it.

SAM SANDERS: But if you're in a public space and you have your AirDrop turned on...

TONY ROMM: Yup.

SAM SANDERS: ...Any other rando (ph) with an iPhone can, like, send you a photo or a gif...

TONY ROMM: Right.

SAM SANDERS: ...Or whatever. It's kind of awesome but kind of scary. It's really scary to me. I have mine turned off all the time.

TONY ROMM: As you should.

KELSEY SNELL: Yes.

SAM SANDERS: Yeah. Apparently, there's a lot of stories out this week that are saying that the kids are using AirDrop to just, like, dump memes and stuff on anyone around them. But there's also this, like, dark underbelly to the AirDrop where, like...

TONY ROMM: (Laughter).

SAM SANDERS: ...A lot of folks on the New York subway will get AirDropped (ph) pictures of bodies.

TONY ROMM: For all the money and smarts in Silicon Valley, you'd think they would have realized by now that if you build it, they will find a way to send dirty pictures using it.

(LAUGHTER)

TONY ROMM: Like, it does not matter what the technology is, what the platform is, people will find...

KELSEY SNELL: The "Field Of Dreams" of tech.

(LAUGHTER)

SAM SANDERS: I love it. All right, we got to talk now about a word that has been creeping its way into the culture over the last few years, and it's become - politically, at least - really divisive. The word is intersectionality. It turns out a lot of folks are using this word, especially online, without really knowing what intersectionality means.

JANE COASTON: So the clearest definition of intersectionality I can give you is that people are complicated, and...

SAM SANDERS: (Laughter).

JANE COASTON: People are not just one thing at one time.

SAM SANDERS: That is Jane Coaston. She covers politics for Vox. And she just wrote this opus on the word intersectionality. It's basically this idea that people can have overlapping identities and be treated differently because of them. So she's saying that you can be a woman and Latina at the same time. You can be gay and Asian American at the same time. And so today politicians use the word intersectionality, even candidates for president. It's being tossed around on Fox News as well, but not too many folks know where the word comes from. And so when you trace it back, the word intersectionality dates back to 1989 when a civil rights professor named Kimberle Crenshaw used the word in an academic paper.

JANE COASTON: Right. This originated in critical race theory, which was a group of legal scholars in the '70s and '80s who were thinking critically about how...

SAM SANDERS: (Laughter).

JANE COASTON: ...Race and identity intersect with the law. And their argument was that the structures that undergird our legal principles in some ways gave credence to racism or, in other ways, you know, were themselves racist.

SAM SANDERS: Well, because there's this case that she's writing about. And it's basically - and fix me if I'm wrong on this - this group of women, black women, are trying to sue their employer for discrimination.

JANE COASTON: Right.

SAM SANDERS: But all of the legal precedents before that basically looks at those kind of suits as you're black and that's it or you're white...

JANE COASTON: Yeah.

SAM SANDERS: ...And that's it. And they...

JANE COASTON: Right.

SAM SANDERS: ...Prescribe remedies based on single identity. And what...

JANE COASTON: Exactly.

SAM SANDERS: ...The women were saying and what Crenshaw was saying is, wait. You can be more than one thing at once, and that gives you a...

JANE COASTON: Precisely.

SAM SANDERS: ...Different outcome.

JANE COASTON: Exactly. Exactly. And so in the - you know, in the case she was talking about, there were specific hiring practices that meant that black women received the brunt of discriminatory action that black men didn't get in that same workplace and white women didn't get in that same workplace. And they were - you know, the intersection of their identities, as being black and being women, was what was enduring discrimination. And, you know, the law wasn't able to see that.

SAM SANDERS: Yeah. Well, and, like, I love how simple the example of these black women is in this case. Basically, the rule in a lot of workplaces is, you know, last hired, first fired.

JANE COASTON: Right.

SAM SANDERS: But in this workplace, for the longest time, they didn't hire women as managers. And they also didn't treat black people fairly. So by virtue of that system, all of these black women managers were, of course, the last hired.

JANE COASTON: Exactly. And so that is a specific form of discrimination that male managers didn't face, white female managers didn't face. It is specifically experienced by black women on the virtue of them being black and being women.

SAM SANDERS: Exactly. So then, all right, intersectionality as a word - it's part of legal theory for a very long time. And something really weird begins to happen a few years ago. And all of a sudden, the word intersectionality is on the Internet and on college campuses and on conservative message boards. What happened?

JANE COASTON: So it's been interesting to track that because, you know, it enter - intersectionality enters the Oxford English Dictionary in, I think, 2015. It starts being kind of the subject of conversation by activists or on college campuses because I think that you saw, you know, the word diversity, you know, didn't - stopped meaning anything in a lot of ways.

SAM SANDERS: Oh, yeah.

JANE COASTON: You know, I think a lot of people - you know, when it's weapons manufacturers bragging about their diverse hiring practices...

SAM SANDERS: (Laughter).

JANE COASTON: ...You know, like...

SAM SANDERS: It's like, really?

JANE COASTON: Especially at a time when - you know, I think 2014, 2015, that's, I think - you start seeing the efforts of Black Lives Matter when you just saw a lot of people who were thinking, OK. What can we be doing here that would make this conversation easier or better or more fruitful? - because clearly, just asking, you know, for a more diverse workplace isn't really getting the job done here.

SAM SANDERS: Yeah. Well, then, also, what's happening at the same time is that the environment and the climate around issues of speech on lots of...

JANE COASTON: Yup.

SAM SANDERS: ...College campuses is just getting...

JANE COASTON: Yup.

SAM SANDERS: ...More heated. And then you see the right glom onto the word intersectionality to kind of push back against those campus climates, right?

JANE COASTON: Right. Exactly. And again, I think the right is responding to how activists or how they perceive activists to be using the term intersectional or intersectionality on college campuses. You know, when I sent a number of conservative writers Kimberle Crenshaw's original paper, you know, they - no one had a problem with it. People were like, oh, yeah. You know, that...

SAM SANDERS: Well, you mean, like, Ben Shapiro and David...

JANE COASTON: Yes.

SAM SANDERS: ...French, like, leading...

JANE COASTON: Yup.

SAM SANDERS: ...Conservative voices said, oh, this theory, on its own...

JANE COASTON: Yup.

SAM SANDERS: ...Is rock solid.

JANE COASTON: Yup. They were like, well, that makes sense. Like...

SAM SANDERS: Wow.

JANE COASTON: ...That sounds fine. Well - and because, I mean, it also is - like, it's breathtakingly simple to argue, in a sense, people are complicated. People have multifaceted identities. But I think it was really this idea that, like, OK. You know, the term isn't bad, but how it's being used is bad.

SAM SANDERS: So then let's talk about that then. How is the left using this term? How is the right using this term? And what do both sides dislike about how the other side is using this term?

JANE COASTON: Well, I think, on the left, intersectionality has been a means by which, you know, you could talk about a lot of different issues that would all impact...

SAM SANDERS: Got you.

JANE COASTON: ...Not a lot of different people but, a lot of times, the same person.

SAM SANDERS: Yeah.

JANE COASTON: You know, I'll use myself as an example. You know, I'm a biracial, gay person. You know, that means that I'm impacted by racism. I'm impacted by sexism. I'm impacted by misogyny. I can also be impacted by homophobia.

SAM SANDERS: Yeah.

JANE COASTON: And all of - it's not as if, you know, people are like, aha - like, you know, people don't divide up your identities when they're being...

SAM SANDERS: Yeah.

JANE COASTON: ...Mean to you.

SAM SANDERS: You are Jane, and all of those things are in you. Yeah.

JANE COASTON: Yeah, exactly, exactly. And so - but I think that something I find fascinating about how the right thought about intersectionality was this idea that it is creating a hierarchy that, you know, at the top of the hierarchy would be - I don't know, hypothetically...

SAM SANDERS: Lesbian black women.

JANE COASTON: ...Black trans women, which would be...

SAM SANDERS: OK, yeah.

JANE COASTON: ...Which would be big news to a lot of black trans women...

SAM SANDERS: (Laughter).

JANE COASTON: ...And that, you know, the victimized will become straight white men - straight cisgender white men, which I found fascinating. And, you know, one - it's kind of acknowledging that there already exists a hierarchy and that you - any effort to eliminate the hierarchy is seen as an effort to simply reverse the hierarchy.

SAM SANDERS: Yeah. So we've talked about how the right has run with this word, but it seems like the left has made the word now almost a religion, almost a belief system. And like, it is - it's spiritual almost.

JANE COASTON: Well, I would say that I think that that is a bit of a canard. I think that for folks who are working on anti-discrimination efforts, they want to use intersectionality, you know, almost in some senses as a signal that makes it clear that they take all forms of discrimination and hate seriously.

SAM SANDERS: So it's like a virtue...

JANE COASTON: And...

SAM SANDERS: ...Signaling.

JANE COASTON: Well, I think virtue signaling would imply that they don't actually think that and that they're doing this just to show people. I think they actually do think that. I think they actually do take discrimination across the board very seriously and are using intersectionality as a means of indicating that, you know, diversity isn't enough, that, you know, this is where we're going to take our stand.

SAM SANDERS: Yeah. My question in this moment, where, like, there's more knowledge available to all of us than ever before, yet people on the left and the right seem to make no effort to really truly understand a word like intersectionality - like, I wonder why that is the case. I would bet that most people could not point to the roots of this word in legal theory.

JANE COASTON: Right.

SAM SANDERS: Is there something about the culture right now or our politics right now that keeps our understanding of these buzzwords so shallow? What is it about us?

JANE COASTON: Well, I think that as our culture has widened to include more voices and more people, how we talk about those voices and people hasn't been. You know, there are a lot more people who have heard Ben Shapiro talk about intersectionality than even, perhaps, I've heard Kimberle Crenshaw talk about intersectionality.

SAM SANDERS: Yeah.

JANE COASTON: And so I think it's when, you know, these kind of secondary actors get to redefine terms. And I'd argue that, you know, the left does this as well, where, you know, you may have heard intersectionality more from college students than you've heard from the original source or if - you know, you may have thought that this is a term that literally just came up in 2015...

SAM SANDERS: Yeah.

JANE COASTON: ...When it most certainly didn't.

SAM SANDERS: Yeah.

JANE COASTON: And so I think that it's when - you know, when secondary actors are able to define terms in our media or to define what something looks like or sounds like, I think that's where that confusion can come from.

(SOUNDBITE OF FLEVANS' "FLICKER")

SAM SANDERS: Thank you, Jane.

JANE COASTON: Of course. Thank you very much.

(SOUNDBITE OF FLEVANS' "FLICKER")

SAM SANDERS: Thanks again to Jane Coaston of Vox. You're listening to IT'S BEEN A MINUTE from NPR. I'm Sam Sanders here with Tony Romm, who covers tech policy for The Washington Post, and Kelsey Snell, who covers Congress for NPR. What do you make of that?

KELSEY SNELL: You know, it - the thing that I thought was really interesting about this is it reminds me of the conversation we have a lot about the word feminism - is it's...

SAM SANDERS: Ah.

KELSEY SNELL: ...Another word where you get into a - it's a complex word that isn't really all that complex, right?

SAM SANDERS: (Laughter) Yeah.

KELSEY SNELL: People create definitions for it based on - you know, because it's shorthand. And...

SAM SANDERS: Exactly.

KELSEY SNELL: ...The problem that we run into in politics here is that people want shorthand because it's a way to connect with voters or with people who they're talking to in a very condensed period of time. But it doesn't actually express the complex feelings that they're having about the topic at hand. And that's where things get difficult.

SAM SANDERS: Yeah.

TONY ROMM: The challenge for us is to figure out how to have that conversation in a way that works for other people while, at the same time, dealing with the fact that there are lots of others with gigantic followings on social media who can kind of co-opt a debate around something like intersectionality to promote a very radically, you know, different or incorrect view of it.

SAM SANDERS: Yeah.

KELSEY SNELL: When you have these kind of conversations, do you get a lot of feedback from people about their feelings about the word?

SAM SANDERS: Well, like, I find with all these conversations, you have to spend 10 or 15 or 20 minutes stripping away the semantics and the jargon from the way people talk about this stuff...

TONY ROMM: Yeah.

SAM SANDERS: ...Because you come to conversations around race and gender with talking points. And it just takes a certain conditioning to strip that back and be really honest about how you feel and what you want. And I think that's what's missing in our politics. And the way that this word has just kind of floundered speaks to that if that makes sense.

KELSEY SNELL: Yeah.

(SOUNDBITE OF FLEVANS' "FLICKER")

SAM SANDERS: Time for a break - when we come back, my favorite game - Who Said That. You're listening to IT'S BEEN A MINUTE from NPR. We'll be right back.

KELSEY SNELL: We were both already terrified about this game.

TONY ROMM: Yeah, we're going to do terribly.

(LAUGHTER)

SAM SANDERS: I don't know why people get so worked up about it.

(SOUNDBITE OF FLEVANS' "FLICKER")

SAM SANDERS: You're listening to IT'S BEEN A MINUTE from NPR, the show where we catch up on the week that was. I'm Sam Sanders, here with two guests - Kelsey Snell, who covers congress for NPR, and Tony Romm, who covers tech policy at The Washington Post. Y'all, it is time for my favorite game - Who Said That.

(SOUNDBITE OF TV SHOW, "THE REAL HOUSEWIVES OF ATLANTA")

KANDI BURRUSS: Who had been saying that?

PORSHA WILLIAMS: Who said that?

SAM SANDERS: The game is really simple. I share a quote from the week. You both have to guess who said that or at least get the story I'm talking about or a keyword from the story. Per usual, the winner gets absolutely nothing.

KELSEY SNELL: Yes.

TONY ROMM: Nice.

SAM SANDERS: Shall we begin?

KELSEY SNELL: Let's do it.

TONY ROMM: Let's do it.

SAM SANDERS: No buzzers - just yell it out, all right? First quote is, "the question I started out with was - how do people perceive what's difficult, and how can we train a computer to make those same types of predictions?"

KELSEY SNELL: A game?

SAM SANDERS: A game show.

TONY ROMM: A game show.

KELSEY SNELL: "Jeopardy!"?

(SOUNDBITE OF VICTORY TUNE)

KELSEY SNELL: Yeah. OK. There you go.

KELSEY SNELL: Oh, really?

SAM SANDERS: See. Yeah, yeah. So that was a quote from Emma Boettcher. She's a new "Jeopardy!" champion. And she...

TONY ROMM: Oh, right.

SAM SANDERS: ...Beat the guy who had won millions with the expertise he gained from being a sports gambler. And she got her expertise in "Jeopardy!" by writing her master's thesis on how to beat the game.

KELSEY SNELL: Wait. I've...

TONY ROMM: See...

KELSEY SNELL: ...Been spending my time all wrong (laughter).

TONY ROMM: I could've gotten a master's in game shows?

KELSEY SNELL: Yeah.

SAM SANDERS: Yes, you can.

TONY ROMM: Why did I do journalism?

KELSEY SNELL: (Laughter).

SAM SANDERS: Yeah. Yeah. She wrote a 70-page master's thesis called "Predicting The Difficulty Of Trivia Questions Using Text Features." And she basically found out that you can figure out how hard these questions are or how easy they are or how to guess the right answer based on how it's worded.

KELSEY SNELL: Wow.

SAM SANDERS: Yeah.

TONY ROMM: She wouldn't struggle at this show. She...

(LAUGHTER)

SAM SANDERS: She'd win it...

TONY ROMM: All of it.

SAM SANDERS: ...Hands down. All right, Kelsey. You're up one - zip. Next quote - you ready?

KELSEY SNELL: Yeah.

SAM SANDERS: "We have decided to launch a campaign to educate the public, politicians and civil servants about the unique problems we face."

KELSEY SNELL: Oh.

TONY ROMM: That could be anything.

KELSEY SNELL: Yeah. I was going to say.

SAM SANDERS: What marginalized community announced this week that they were going to have a march to celebrate themselves?

KELSEY SNELL: Oh.

TONY ROMM: Is this the straight pride thing?

KELSEY SNELL: Straight pride?

(SOUNDBITE OF VICTORY TUNE)

SAM SANDERS: Yes.

TONY ROMM: Oh, Jesus.

SAM SANDERS: I'll give that to both of you.

KELSEY SNELL: (Laughter).

TONY ROMM: Oh, no.

SAM SANDERS: So as we know, June is LGBTQ Pride month, and there are parades and celebrations and honoring of that community all month. But in response, a group called Super Happy Fun America wrote a blog post this week announcing that, in the Boston area, these guys are planning a straight pride parade.

TONY ROMM: What's in it?

SAM SANDERS: I don't even know - cargo shorts?

KELSEY SNELL: Socks and sandals.

(LAUGHTER)

TONY ROMM: I have no words.

SAM SANDERS: All right. Final quote - I think the game is - well, the game is whatever. It doesn't matter. Final quote...

(LAUGHTER)

SAM SANDERS: Here's a quote. "Tonight's the night. Let's live it up. I got my money. Let's spend it up." Y'all know that quote.

KELSEY SNELL: I...

SAM SANDERS: It's from a song.

KELSEY SNELL: It is from a song.

TONY ROMM: Yeah, I know. And I'm like - I'm going to embarrass myself.

KELSEY SNELL: I love - no.

SAM SANDERS: Let me do it again. Tonight's the night.

TONY ROMM: That's what it sounded like to...

SAM SANDERS: Let's live it up.

KELSEY SNELL: Oh, it's...

SAM SANDERS: I got my money. Let's spend it up...

KELSEY SNELL: I know this. The...

TONY ROMM: Black Eyed Peas.

(SOUNDBITE OF VICTORY TUNE)

SAM SANDERS: Yes. Oh, my God.

KELSEY SNELL: Gosh. We're dragging over here.

TONY ROMM: Oh, my God.

SAM SANDERS: Why was it so hard?

TONY ROMM: I don't know.

KELSEY SNELL: What really happened there is Tony and I totally knew the answer.

SAM SANDERS: Uh-huh.

KELSEY SNELL: We just wanted to hear you sing again - twice.

SAM SANDERS: Uh-huh.

TONY ROMM: Twice, yeah.

KELSEY SNELL: (Laughter).

SAM SANDERS: So I was reciting some of the lyrics of the Black Eyed Peas' classic "I Gotta Feeling" because, to the best of our knowledge from what Apple has revealed, that has been the best-selling song on iTunes.

TONY ROMM: Oh.

KELSEY SNELL: Really?

SAM SANDERS: And iTunes is in the news this week because Apple is kind of killing iTunes. iTunes is over.

TONY ROMM: Yep. RIP.

KELSEY SNELL: I'm not going to be sad about that.

TONY ROMM: RIP, iTunes.

SAM SANDERS: Basically, iTunes allows you to, like, download songs. Now we've all moved to streaming. Right?

TONY ROMM: Yeah, yeah. I mean - and also, that software is terrible, and nobody likes using it. Whenever it opens up your laptop, you're like, damn this thing. It's like (laughter)....

SAM SANDERS: Yeah, yeah.

KELSEY SNELL: I mean, I'm pretty sure I still have a phone somewhere that has that U2 album that they made you get from iTunes on your phone.

TONY ROMM: Oh, my God.

SAM SANDERS: God.

KELSEY SNELL: Remember that?

SAM SANDERS: So annoying.

TONY ROMM: Right.

SAM SANDERS: So annoying.

TONY ROMM: Yeah. But they're, like, splitting it up into multiple things now. So it's like sort of gone but not gone.

SAM SANDERS: Yeah. So like, you can still use iTunes and download the song. But it'll be hidden, and Apple's going to prioritize streaming. But this is just a sign that, like, the industry has changed. You know, when iTunes came out, everyone wanted to download their songs and have them on their device. And now we've moved to streaming, and people just download this stuff less. So RIP.

KELSEY SNELL: Maybe they should just download podcasts more.

SAM SANDERS: Ba-da-ba (ph).

KELSEY SNELL: NPR plugs.

(LAUGHTER)

SAM SANDERS: All right. Anyways, the game is oh (ph) - who won?

TONY ROMM: Not me.

SAM SANDERS: I really don't know.

TONY ROMM: (Laughter) Celine Dion won.

SAM SANDERS: That's right.

KELSEY SNELL: At the end of the day, Celine is the winner.

(LAUGHTER)

SAM SANDERS: Now it's time to end the show. Usually in this segment, we ask our listeners to share with us the best things that happened to them all week. We encourage folks to brag. We listen. It's always great. But this week, want to try something different. We have been asking listeners to share with us the strangest, weirdest, quirkiest parts of their week. We wanted folks to give us that audio. So we've put it together.

Brent, Anjuli - hit the tape.

IAN DOESCHER: Hi, Sam. This Ian Doescher (ph) from Portland, Ore. Here's the weirdest thing that happened to me this week. My sons and I were on vacation in New York City. And while we walked through Central Park, we overheard snippets of conversations. One person said, and then if you accidentally eat the child...

(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)

IAN DOESCHER: ...Not sure what that was about.

(LAUGHTER)

KELSEY SNELL: OK.

(LAUGHTER)

MAGGIE RINEY: Hi, Sam. Maggie Riney (ph) here. Something weird that happened to me this week is that I was returning from a local amusement park in Santa Claus, Ind., actually named Holiday World when a bald eagle swooped down, talons blazing, and almost landed on the hood of my car.

MELINDA: I was sitting on a bench on my patio with a cup of coffee in one hand and the hose in the other watering the plants, and a skunk walked across my feet. I think it was the weirdest thing that happened to the skunk, too.

(LAUGHTER)

JASMINE: I recently started watching "Sex And The City" because I had never seen it. And last night, I came across the episode where the Russian hands Carrie a banana and tells her to put it in her purse. Today as I was walking to dinner, I said hello to my fruit stand guy, and he gave me a big hug, said hello and then gave me a banana to take with me. And since I was on my way to dinner, decided to save it for later by putting it in my purse.

(LAUGHTER)

SAMANTHA: Hey, Sam. This is Samantha (ph). I had something really weird but special happen this past week. It was about my dad. He was a nurse, and I followed in his footsteps. This past week, there was a day I was feeling really down because I thought about how he wasn't around to trade crazy nursing stories or give me instructions on things. But when I was asked to start an IV on a patient, I thought about the instructions he'd given me a really long time ago - how to look for a site, how to approach it. I got the IV in one try and started talking with the patient only to realize that she had known my father once upon a time because he had hired her to work with him in the surgical department 15 years ago. She shared with me how well-liked he had been and how he always liked to laugh. She was right. He always liked to laugh. And that was the weird, special and awesome thing that happened to me this past week.

JASMINE: Thanks so much. Have a good weekend.

IAN DOESCHER: Thanks for everything you do, Sam.

SAM SANDERS: My goodness.

KELSEY SNELL: I'm also still a little hung up on, A, Santa Claus, Ind., and, B, a local amusement park. Like, there's a lot going on in that story.

TONY ROMM: I want a fruit stand guy.

KELSEY SNELL: (Laughter).

SAM SANDERS: Our listeners are pretty great. Oh, my goodness. Thanks to all those listeners - Ian, Maggie, Melinda (ph), Jasmine (ph) and Samantha. We listen to and read everything you send us, so keep it coming. Send me the sound of your voice. Send me an email or a note. Email all that stuff to samsanders@npr.org - samsanders@npr.org All right. That's a wrap. The two of y'all were the best parts of my week.

KELSEY SNELL: Aw.

TONY ROMM: Aw.

SAM SANDERS: Thanks to Tony Romm, who covers tech policy at the Washington Post, for being here this week and Kelsey Snell, who covers Congress for NPR.

KELSEY SNELL: Thanks for having us.

TONY ROMM: Yeah, thanks.

SAM SANDERS: This week, IT'S BEEN A MINUTE was produced by Brent Baughman and Anjuli Sastry. Steve Nelson is our director of programming. Our fearless editors are Jordana Hochman and Alex McCall. And our big boss is NPR's senior VP of programming Anya Grundmann. All right, listeners, till next time - thank you for listening. I'm Sam Sanders. Talk soon. Keep channeling your inner Celine.

(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, "THAT'S THE WAY IT IS")

CELINE DION: (Singing) That's the way it is. That's the way it is. Don't give up on your faith. Love comes to those who believe it, and that's the way it is.

AUNT BETTY: Hey, y'all. This is Sam's Aunt Betty.

AUNT DONNA: And Sam's Aunt Donna on the West Coast.

AUNT BETTY: This week on the show, Washington Post technology reporter Tony Romm.

AUNT DONNA: And NPR congressional correspondent Kelsey Snell. All right. Let's start the show.

AUNT BETTY: All right. Let's start the show.

(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, "THAT'S THE WAY IT IS")

CELINE DION: (Singing) Yeah.

SAM SANDERS: Hey, y'all. From NPR, I'm Sam Sanders. IT'S BEEN A MINUTE.

KELSEY SNELL: That was great.

TONY ROMM: (Laughter).

SAM SANDERS: Double the aunties. So Aunt Betty came to California to visit me and other relatives.

KELSEY SNELL: I saw the pictures. Did she bring treats to the whole newsroom?

SAM SANDERS: She brought a pound cake to NPR West.

TONY ROMM: What?

KELSEY SNELL: (Laughter).

SAM SANDERS: She was a hit. And then she went to visit my other aunt, Donna, in San Diego. And they both announced you this week. It was really sweet.

KELSEY SNELL: Aw.

SAM SANDERS: I know. I know. Speaking of sweet things, (laughter), happy weekend to our listeners and to my guests, Tony Romm, reporter at The Washington Post covering technology policy, and Kelsey Snell, who covers Congress for NPR. Both of you are old friends. I'm happy to have all of this friendship in studio with me.

JANE COASTON: ...When it most certainly didn't.

SAM SANDERS: Yeah.

JANE COASTON: And so I think that it's when - you know, when secondary actors are able to define terms in our media or to define what something looks like or sounds like, I think that's where that confusion can come from.

(SOUNDBITE OF FLEVANS' "FLICKER")

SAM SANDERS: Thank you, Jane.

JANE COASTON: Of course. Thank you very much.

(SOUNDBITE OF FLEVANS' "FLICKER")

SAM SANDERS: Thanks again to Jane Coaston of Vox. You're listening to IT'S BEEN A MINUTE from NPR. I'm Sam Sanders here with Tony Romm, who covers tech policy for The Washington Post, and Kelsey Snell, who covers Congress for NPR. What do you make of that?

KELSEY SNELL: You know, it - the thing that I thought was really interesting about this is it reminds me of the conversation we have a lot about the word feminism - is it's...

SAM SANDERS: Ah.

KELSEY SNELL: ...Another word where you get into a - it's a complex word that isn't really all that complex, right?

SAM SANDERS: (Laughter) Yeah.

KELSEY SNELL: People create definitions for it based on - you know, because it's shorthand. And...

SAM SANDERS: Exactly.

KELSEY SNELL: ...The problem that we run into in politics here is that people want shorthand because it's a way to connect with voters or with people who they're talking to in a very condensed period of time. But it doesn't actually express the complex feelings that they're having about the topic at hand. And that's where things get difficult.

SAM SANDERS: Yeah.

TONY ROMM: The challenge for us is to figure out how to have that conversation in a way that works for other people while, at the same time, dealing with the fact that there are lots of others with gigantic followings on social media who can kind of co-opt a debate around something like intersectionality to promote a very radically, you know, different or incorrect view of it.

SAM SANDERS: Yeah.

KELSEY SNELL: When you have these kind of conversations, do you get a lot of feedback from people about their feelings about the word?

SAM SANDERS: Well, like, I find with all these conversations, you have to spend 10 or 15 or 20 minutes stripping away the semantics and the jargon from the way people talk about this stuff...

TONY ROMM: Yeah.

SAM SANDERS: ...Because you come to conversations around race and gender with talking points. And it just takes a certain conditioning to strip that back and be really honest about how you feel and what you want. And I think that's what's missing in our politics. And the way that this word has just kind of floundered speaks to that if that makes sense.

KELSEY SNELL: Yeah.

(SOUNDBITE OF FLEVANS' "FLICKER")

SAM SANDERS: Time for a break - when we come back, my favorite game - Who Said That. You're listening to IT'S BEEN A MINUTE from NPR. We'll be right back.

KELSEY SNELL: We were both already terrified about this game.

TONY ROMM: Yeah, we're going to do terribly.

(LAUGHTER)

SAM SANDERS: I don't know why people get so worked up about it.

(SOUNDBITE OF FLEVANS' "FLICKER")

SAM SANDERS: You're listening to IT'S BEEN A MINUTE from NPR, the show where we catch up on the week that was. I'm Sam Sanders, here with two guests - Kelsey Snell, who covers congress for NPR, and Tony Romm, who covers tech policy at The Washington Post. Y'all, it is time for my favorite game - Who Said That.

(SOUNDBITE OF TV SHOW, "THE REAL HOUSEWIVES OF ATLANTA")

KANDI BURRUSS: Who had been saying that?

PORSHA WILLIAMS: Who said that?

SAM SANDERS: The game is really simple. I share a quote from the week. You both have to guess who said that or at least get the story I'm talking about or a keyword from the story. Per usual, the winner gets absolutely nothing.

KELSEY SNELL: Yes.

TONY ROMM: Nice.

SAM SANDERS: Shall we begin?

KELSEY SNELL: Let's do it.

TONY ROMM: Let's do it.

SAM SANDERS: No buzzers - just yell it out, all right? First quote is, "the question I started out with was - how do people perceive what's difficult, and how can we train a computer to make those same types of predictions?"

KELSEY SNELL: A game?

SAM SANDERS: A game show.

TONY ROMM: A game show.

KELSEY SNELL: "Jeopardy!"?

(SOUNDBITE OF VICTORY TUNE)

KELSEY SNELL: Yeah. OK. There you go.

KELSEY SNELL: Oh, really?

SAM SANDERS: See. Yeah, yeah. So that was a quote from Emma Boettcher. She's a new "Jeopardy!" champion. And she...

TONY ROMM: Oh, right.

SAM SANDERS: ...Beat the guy who had won millions with the expertise he gained from being a sports gambler. And she got her expertise in "Jeopardy!" by writing her master's thesis on how to beat the game.

KELSEY SNELL: Wait. I've...

TONY ROMM: See...

KELSEY SNELL: ...Been spending my time all wrong (laughter).

TONY ROMM: I could've gotten a master's in game shows?

KELSEY SNELL: Yeah.

SAM SANDERS: Yes, you can.

TONY ROMM: Why did I do journalism?

KELSEY SNELL: (Laughter).

SAM SANDERS: Yeah. Yeah. She wrote a 70-page master's thesis called "Predicting The Difficulty Of Trivia Questions Using Text Features." And she basically found out that you can figure out how hard these questions are or how easy they are or how to guess the right answer based on how it's worded.

KELSEY SNELL: Wow.

SAM SANDERS: Yeah.

TONY ROMM: She wouldn't struggle at this show. She...

(LAUGHTER)

SAM SANDERS: She'd win it...

TONY ROMM: All of it.

SAM SANDERS: ...Hands down. All right, Kelsey. You're up one - zip. Next quote - you ready?

KELSEY SNELL: Yeah.

SAM SANDERS: "We have decided to launch a campaign to educate the public, politicians and civil servants about the unique problems we face."

KELSEY SNELL: Oh.

TONY ROMM: That could be anything.

KELSEY SNELL: Yeah. I was going to say.

SAM SANDERS: What marginalized community announced this week that they were going to have a march to celebrate themselves?

KELSEY SNELL: Oh.

TONY ROMM: Is this the straight pride thing?

KELSEY SNELL: Straight pride?

(SOUNDBITE OF VICTORY TUNE)

SAM SANDERS: Yes.

TONY ROMM: Oh, Jesus.

SAM SANDERS: I'll give that to both of you.

KELSEY SNELL: (Laughter).

TONY ROMM: Oh, no.

SAM SANDERS: So as we know, June is LGBTQ Pride month, and there are parades and celebrations and honoring of that community all month. But in response, a group called Super Happy Fun America wrote a blog post this week announcing that, in the Boston area, these guys are planning a straight pride parade.

TONY ROMM: What's in it?

SAM SANDERS: I don't even know - cargo shorts?

KELSEY SNELL: Socks and sandals.

(LAUGHTER)

TONY ROMM: I have no words.

SAM SANDERS: All right. Final quote - I think the game is - well, the game is whatever. It doesn't matter. Final quote...

Brent, Anjuli - hit the tape.

(LAUGHTER)

This past week, there was a day I was feeling really down because I thought about how he wasn't around to trade crazy nursing stories or give me instructions on things. But when I was asked to start an IV on a patient, I thought about the instructions he'd given me a really long time ago - how to look for a site, how to approach it. I got the IV in one try and started talking with the patient only to realize that she had known my father once upon a time because he had hired her to work with him in the surgical department 15 years ago. SAM SANDERS: My goodness.

KELSEY SNELL: I'm also still a little hung up on, A, Santa Claus, Ind., and, B, a local amusement park. Like, there's a lot going on in that story.

TONY ROMM: I want a fruit stand guy.

KELSEY SNELL: (Laughter).

SAM SANDERS: Our listeners are pretty great. Oh, my goodness. Thanks to all those listeners - Ian, Maggie, Melinda (ph), Jasmine (ph) and Samantha. We listen to and read everything you send us, so keep it coming. Send me the sound of your voice. Send me an email or a note. Email all that stuff to samsanders@npr.org - samsanders@npr.org All right. That's a wrap. The two of y'all were the best parts of my week.

KELSEY SNELL: Aw.

TONY ROMM: Aw.

SAM SANDERS: Thanks to Tony Romm, who covers tech policy at the Washington Post, for being here this week and Kelsey Snell, who covers Congress for NPR.

KELSEY SNELL: Thanks for having us.

TONY ROMM: Yeah, thanks.

SAM SANDERS: This week, IT'S BEEN A MINUTE was produced by Brent Baughman and Anjuli Sastry. Steve Nelson is our director of programming. Our fearless editors are Jordana Hochman and Alex McCall. And our big boss is NPR's senior VP of programming Anya Grundmann. All right, listeners, till next time - thank you for listening. I'm Sam Sanders. Talk soon. Keep channeling your inner Celine.
